# The Epic of Gilgamish

## by

Stephen Langdon

## University of Pennsylvania

The University Museum

Publications of the Babylonian Section

Vol. X No. 3

[ [207](#d0e100) ]

## Introduction

In the year 1914 the University Museum secured by purchase a large six column tablet nearly complete, carrying originally,
according to the scribal note, 240 lines of text. The contents supply the South Babylonian version of the second book of the
epic *Å¡a nagba imuru*, â€œHe who has seen all things,â€ commonly referred to as the Epic of Gilgamish. The tablet is said to have been found at Senkere,
ancient Larsa near Warka, modern Arabic name for and vulgar descendant of the ancient name Uruk, the Biblical Erech mentioned
in Genesis X. 10. This fact makes the new text the more interesting since the legend of Gilgamish is said to have originated
at Erech and the hero in fact figures as one of the prehistoric Sumerian rulers of that ancient city. The dynastic list preserved
on a Nippur tablet[1](#d0e109) mentions him as the fifth king of a legendary line of rulers at Erech, who succeeded the dynasty of Kish, a city in North
Babylonia near the more famous but more recent city Babylon. The list at Erech contains the names of two well known Sumerian
deities, Lugalbanda[2](#d0e115) and Tammuz. The reign of the former is given at 1,200 years and that of Tammuz at 100 years. Gilgamish ruled 126 years. We
have to do here with a confusion of myth and history in which the real facts are disengaged only by conjecture.

The prehistoric Sumerian dynasties were all transformed [ [208](#d0e120) ]into the realm of myth and legend. Nevertheless these rulers, although appearing in the pretentious nomenclature as gods,
appear to have been real historic personages.[3](#d0e122) The name Gilgamish was originally written *d Gi-bil-aga-miÅ¡* , and means â€œThe fire god ( *Gibil* ) is a commander,â€ abbreviated to *d Gi-bil-ga-miÅ¡* , and *d Gi(Å¡)-bil-ga-miÅ¡* , a form which by full labialization of *b* to *uÌ¯* was finally contracted to *d Gi-il-ga-miÅ¡* . [4](#d0e166) Throughout the new text the name is written with the abbreviation *d Gi(Å¡)* , [5](#d0e177) whereas the standard Assyrian text has consistently the writing *d GIÅ -á¹¬U 6 -BAR* . The latter method of writing the name is apparently cryptographic for *d GiÅ¡-bar-aga-(miÅ¡)* ; the fire god *Gibil* has also the title *GiÅ¡-bar*.

A fragment of the South Babylonian version of the tenth book was published in 1902, a text from the period of Hammurapi, which
showed that the Babylonian epic differed very much from the Assyrian in diction, but not in content. The new tablet, which
belongs to the same period, also differs radically from the diction of the Ninevite text in the few lines where they duplicate
each other. The first line of the new tablet corresponds to Tablet I, Col. V 25 of the Assyrian text,[7](#d0e210) where Gilgamish begins to relate his dreams to his mother Ninsun. [8](#d0e219) [ [209](#d0e246) ]

The last line of Col. I corresponds to the Assyrian version Book I, Col. VI 29. From this point onward the new tablet takes
up a hitherto unknown portion of the epic, henceforth to be assigned to the second book.[9](#d0e249)

At the end of Book I in the Assyrian text and at the end of Col. I of Book II in the new text, the situation in the legend
is as follows. The harlot halts outside the city of Erech with the enamoured Enkidu, while she relates to him the two dreams
of the king, Gilgamish. In these dreams which he has told to his mother he receives premonition concerning the advent of the
satyr Enkidu, destined to join with him in the conquest of Elam.

Now the harlot urges Enkidu to enter the beautiful city, to clothe himself like other men and to learn the ways of civilization.
When he enters he sees someone, whose name is broken away, eating bread and drinking milk, but the beautiful barbarian understands
not. The harlot commands him to eat and drink also:

â€œIt is the conformity of life,

Of the conditions and fate of the Land.â€

He rapidly learns the customs of men, becomes a shepherd and a mighty hunter. At last he comes to the notice of Gilgamish
himself, who is shocked by the newly acquired manner of Enkidu.

â€œOh harlot, take away the man,â€ says the lord of Erech. Once again the faithful woman instructs her heroic lover in the conventions
of society, this time teaching him the importance of the family in Babylonian life, and obedience to the ruler. Now the people
of Erech assemble about him admiring his [ [210](#d0e265) ]godlike appearance. Gilgamish receives him and they dedicate their arms to heroic endeavor. At this point the epic brings
in a new and powerful *motif*, the renunciation of womanâ€™s love in the presence of a great undertaking. Gilgamish is enamoured of the beautiful virgin
goddess IÅ¡hara, and Enkidu, fearing the effeminate effects of his friendâ€™s attachment, prevents him forcibly from entering
a house. A terrific combat between these heroes ensues,[10](#d0e270) in which Enkidu conquers, and in a magnanimous speech he reminds Gilgamish of his higher destiny.

In another unplaced fragment of the Assyrian text [11](#d0e278) Enkidu rejects his mistress also, apparently on his own initiative and for ascetic reasons. This fragment, heretofore assigned
to the second book, probably belongs to Book III. The tablet of the Assyrian version which carries the portion related on
the new tablet has not been found. Man redeemed from barbarism is the major theme of Book II.

The newly recovered section of the epic contains two legends which supplied the glyptic artists of Sumer and Accad with subjects
for seals. Obverse III 28â€“32 describes Enkidu the slayer of lions and panthers. Seals in all periods frequently represent
Enkidu in combat with a lion. The struggle between the two heroes, where Enkidu strives to rescue his friend from the fatal
charms of IÅ¡hara, is probably depicted on seals also. On one of the seals published by Ward, *Seal Cylinders of Western Asia* , No. 459, a nude female stands beside the struggling heroes. [12](#d0e292) This scene not improbably illustrates the effort of Enkidu to rescue his friend from the goddess. In fact the satyr stands
between Gilgamish and IÅ¡hara(?) on the seal.
[ [211](#d0e295) ]

---

[1](#d0e109src) Ni. 13981, published by Dr. Poebel in PBS. V, No. 2.

[2](#d0e115src) The local BÃªl of Erech and a bye-form of Enlil, the earth god. Here he is the consort of the mother goddess Ninsun.

[3](#d0e122src) Tammuz is probably a real personage, although *Dumu-zi* , his original name, is certainly later than the title *Ab-Ãº* , probably the oldest epithet of this deity, see *Tammuz and Ishtar* , p. 8. *Dumu-zi* I take to have been originally the name of a prehistoric ruler of Erech, identified with the primitive deity Abu.

[4](#d0e166src) See *ibid.*, page 40.

[5](#d0e177src) Also Meissnerâ€™s early Babylonian duplicate of Book X has invariably the same writing, see Dhorme, *Choix de Textes Religieux*, 298â€“303.

[6](#d0e190src) Sign whose gunufied form is read *aga*.

[7](#d0e210src) The standard text of the Assyrian version is by Professor Paul Haupt, *Das Babylonische Nimrodepos*, Leipzig, 1884.

[8](#d0e219src) The name of the mother of Gilgamish has been erroneously read *ri-mat ilat Nin-lil* , or *Rimat-BÃªlit* , see Dhorme 202, 37; 204, 30, etc. But Dr. Poebel, who also copied this text, has shown that *Nin-lil* is an erroneous reading for *Nin-sun* . For *Ninsun* as mother of Gilgamish see SBP. 153 n. 19 and R.A., IX 113 III 2. *Ri-mat ilat Nin-sun* should be rendered â€œThe wild cow Ninsun.â€

[9](#d0e249src) The fragments which have been assigned to Book II in the British Museum collections by Haupt, Jensen, Dhorme and others belong
to later tablets, probably III or IV.

[10](#d0e270src) Rm. 289, latter part of Col. II (part of the Assyrian version) published in HAUPT, *ibid.*, 81â€“4 preserves a defective text of this part of the epic. This tablet has been erroneously assigned to Book IV, but it appears
to be Book III.

[11](#d0e278src) K. 2589 and duplicate (unnumbered) in Haupt, *ibid.*, 16â€“19.

[12](#d0e292src) See also Ward, No. 199.

# Beowulf: An Anglo-Saxon Epic Poem

## THE LIFE AND DEATH OF SCYLD.

The famous race of Spear-Danes.  
Lo! the Spear-Danesâ€™ glory through splendid achievements  
The folk-kingsâ€™ former fame we have heard of,  
How princes displayed then their prowess-in-battle.  

Oft Scyld the Scefing from scathers in numbers  
From many a people their mead-benches tore.  
Since first he found him friendless and wretched,  
The earl had had terror: comfort he got for it,  
Waxed â€™neath the welkin, world-honor gained,  
Till all his neighbors oâ€™er sea were compelled to  
Bow to his bidding and bring him their tribute:  
An excellent atheling! After was borne him  
A son and heir, young in his dwelling,  
Whom God-Father sent to solace the people.  
He had marked the misery malice had caused them,  
That reaved of their rulers they wretched had erstwhile  
Long been afflicted. The Lord, in requital,  
Wielder of Glory, with world-honor blessed him.  
Famed was Beowulf, far spread the glory  
Of Scyldâ€™s great son in the lands of the Danemen.  

So the carle that is young, by kindnesses rendered  
The friends of his father, with fees in abundance  
Must be able to earn that when age approacheth  
Eager companions aid him requitingly,  
When war assaults him serve him as liegemen:  
By praise-worthy actions must honor be got  
â€™Mong all of the races. At the hour that was fated  
Scyld then departed to the All-Fatherâ€™s keeping  
Warlike to wend him; away then they bare him  
To the flood of the current, his fond-loving comrades,  
As himself he had bidden, while the friend of the Scyldings  
Word-sway wielded, and the well-lovÃ¨d land-prince  
Long did rule them. The ring-stemmÃ¨d vessel,  
Bark of the atheling, lay there at anchor,  
Icy in glimmer and eager for sailing;  
The belovÃ¨d leader laid they down there,  
Giver of rings, on the breast of the vessel,  
The famed by the mainmast. A many of jewels,  
Of fretted embossings, from far-lands brought over,  
Was placed near at hand then; and heard I not ever  
That a folk ever furnished a float more superbly  
With weapons of warfare, weeds for the battle,  
Bills and burnies; on his bosom sparkled  
Many a jewel that with him must travel  
On the flush of the flood afar on the current.  
And favors no fewer they furnished him soothly,  
Excellent folk-gems, than others had given him  
Who when first he was born outward did send him  
Lone on the main, the merest of infants:  
And a gold-fashioned standard they stretched under heaven  
High oâ€™er his head, let the holm-currents bear him,  
Seaward consigned him: sad was their spirit,  
Their mood very mournful. Men are not able  
Soothly to tell us, they in halls who reside,  
Heroes under heaven, to what haven he hied.  

## SCYLDâ€™S SUCCESSORS.â€”HROTHGARâ€™S GREAT MEAD-HALL.

In the boroughs then Beowulf, bairn of the Scyldings,  
BelovÃ¨d land-prince, for long-lasting season  
Was famed mid the folk (his father departed,  
The prince from his dwelling), till afterward sprang  
Great-minded Healfdene; the Danes in his lifetime  
He graciously governed, grim-mooded, agÃ¨d.  

Four bairns of his body born in succession  
Woke in the world, war-troopersâ€™ leader  
Heorogar, Hrothgar, and Halga the good;  
Heard I that Elan was Ongentheowâ€™s consort,  
The well-beloved bedmate of the War-Scylfing leader.  

Then glory in battle to Hrothgar was given,  
Waxing of war-fame, that willingly kinsmen  
Obeyed his bidding, till the boys grew to manhood,  
A numerous band. It burned in his spirit  
To urge his folk to found a great building,  
A mead-hall grander than men of the era  
Ever had heard of, and in it to share  
With young and old all of the blessings  
The Lord had allowed him, save life and retainers.  
Then the work I find afar was assigned  
To many races in middle-earthâ€™s regions,  
To adorn the great folk-hall. In due time it happened  
Early â€™mong men, that â€™twas finished entirely,  
The greatest of hall-buildings; Heorot he named it  
Who wide-reaching word-sway wielded â€™mong earlmen.  
His promise he brake not, rings he lavished,  
Treasure at banquet. Towered the hall up  
High and horn-crested, huge between antlers:  
It battle-waves bided, the blasting fire-demon;  
Ere long then from hottest hatred must sword-wrath  
Arise for a womanâ€™s husband and father.  

Then the mighty war-spirit endured for a season,  
Bore it bitterly, he who bided in darkness,  
That light-hearted laughter loud in the building  
Greeted him daily; there was dulcet harp-music,  
Clear song of the singer. He said that was able  
To tell from of old earthmenâ€™s beginnings,  
That Father Almighty earth had created,  
The winsome wold that the water encircleth,  
Set exultingly the sunâ€™s and the moonâ€™s beams  
To lavish their lustre on land-folk and races,  
And earth He embellished in all her regions  
With limbs and leaves; life He bestowed too  
On all the kindreds that live under heaven.  

So blessed with abundance, brimming with joyance,  
The warriors abided, till a certain one gan to  
Dog them with deeds of direfullest malice,  
A foe in the hall-building: this horrible stranger  
Was Grendel entitled, the march-stepper famous  
Who dwelt in the moor-fens, the marsh and the fastness;  
The wan-mooded being abode for a season  
In the land of the giants, when the Lord and Creator  
Had banned him and branded. For that bitter murder,  
The killing of Abel, all-ruling Father  
The kindred of Cain crushed with His vengeance;  
In the feud He rejoiced not, but far away drove him  
From kindred and kind, that crime to atone for,  
Meter of Justice. Thence ill-favored creatures,  
Elves and giants, monsters of ocean,  
Came into being, and the giants that longtime  
Grappled with God; He gave them requital.  

## GRENDEL THE MURDERER.

When the sun was sunken, he set out to visit  
The lofty hall-building, how the Ring-Danes had used it  
For beds and benches when the banquet was over.  
Then he found there reposing many a noble  
Asleep after supper; sorrow the heroes,  
Misery knew not. The monster of evil  
Greedy and cruel tarried but little,  
Fell and frantic, and forced from their slumbers  
Thirty of thanemen; thence he departed  
Leaping and laughing, his lair to return to,  
With surfeit of slaughter sallying homeward.  

In the dusk of the dawning, as the day was just breaking,  
Was Grendelâ€™s prowess revealed to the warriors:  
Then, his meal-taking finished, a moan was uplifted,  
Morning-cry mighty. The man-ruler famous,  
The long-worthy atheling, sat very woful,  
Suffered great sorrow, sighed for his liegemen,  
When they had seen the track of the hateful pursuer,  
The spirit accursÃ¨d: too crushing that sorrow,  
Too loathsome and lasting. Not longer he tarried,  
But one night after continued his slaughter  
Shameless and shocking, shrinking but little  
From malice and murder; they mastered him fully.  
He was easy to find then who otherwhere looked for  
A pleasanter place of repose in the lodges,  
A bed in the bowers. Then was brought to his notice  
Told him truly by token apparent  
The hall-thaneâ€™s hatred: he held himself after  
Further and faster who the foeman did baffle.  
So ruled he and strongly strove against justice  
Lone against all men, till empty uptowered  
The choicest of houses. Long was the season:  
Twelve-wintersâ€™ time torture suffered  
The friend of the Scyldings, every affliction,  
Endless agony; hence it after became  
Certainly known to the children of men  
Sadly in measures, that long against Hrothgar  
Grendel struggled:â€”his grudges he cherished,  
Murderous malice, many a winter,  
Strife unremitting, and peacefully wished he  
Life-woe to lift from no liegeman at all of  
The men of the Dane-folk, for money to settle,  
No counsellor needed count for a moment  
On handsome amends at the hands of the murderer;  
The monster of evil fiercely did harass,  
The ill-planning death-shade, both elder and younger,  
Trapping and tricking them. He trod every night then  
The mist-covered moor-fens; men do not know where  
Witches and wizards wander and ramble.  
So the foe of mankind many of evils  
Grievous injuries, often accomplished,  
Horrible hermit; Heort he frequented,  
Gem-bedecked palace, when night-shades had fallen  
(Since God did oppose him, not the throne could he touch,  
The light-flashing jewel, love of Him knew not).  
â€™Twas a fearful affliction to the friend of the Scyldings  
Soul-crushing sorrow. Not seldom in private  
Sat the king in his council; conference held they  
What the braves should determine â€™gainst terrors unlooked for.  
At the shrines of their idols often they promised  
Gifts and offerings, earnestly prayed they  
The devil from hell would help them to lighten  
Their peopleâ€™s oppression. Such practice they used then,  
Hope of the heathen; hell they remembered  
In innermost spirit, God they knew not,  
The true God they do not know.  
Judge of their actions, All-wielding Ruler,  
No praise could they give the Guardian of Heaven,  
The Wielder of Glory. Woe will be his who  
Through furious hatred his spirit shall drive to  
The clutch of the fire, no comfort shall look for,  
Wax no wiser; well for the man who,  
Living his life-days, his Lord may face  
And find defence in his Fatherâ€™s embrace!

texts.text:
**Prologue (Lines 1-19)** After the fall of Troy, Aeneas, the most faithful knight, flees with his kin, settles in Italy, and founds Rome; Romulus builds Rome and names it after himself; Ticius founds Tuscany; Langaberde raises homes in Lombardy; Felix Brutus crosses the French flood (sea) and settles in Britain, establishing a land of war, wonder, strife, and shifting bliss and blunder.

**II (Lines 20-39)** Bold men increase in Britain; many marvels occur there, more than elsewhere since that time; Arthur is deemed the noblest of Britain's kings; the poet announces an outrageous adventure of Arthur's wonders, urging listeners to hear the tale as heard in town, rooted in strong, loyal verse.

**III (Lines 40-59)** Arthur holds Christmas feast at Camelot with Round Table knights, rich revelry, jousting, and carols for fifteen days; joy fills halls and chambers with lords, ladies, brave knights, and lovely women, including the comeliest king and queen, making them the happiest under heaven.

**IV (Lines 60-87)** New Year arrives with double dawn; chapel chant ends, clerks cry "Nowel"; gifts are exchanged amid laughter; Arthur refuses to eat until served, awaiting a wondrous adventure of marvels, arms, or knights in jeopardy, reflecting his bold mirth among friends.

**V (Lines 88-119)** Arthur's youth and nobility make him delay eating without a devised adventure; king converses with knights like Gawain, Agravayn, Bishop Bawdewyn, and Ywain; first course served with trumpets, banners, and dainties, each person having twelve dishes, good beer, and bright wine.

**VI (Lines 120-151)** No lack of service; sudden noise as a massive, tall knight enters, broader than tall, with long limbs, great back and breast but small waist; hall rejoices; he is hailed as the merriest and most mannerly, father of nurture, promising lessons in courtly love.

texts.name: Canterbury Tales General Prologue
texts.text:
The Canterbury Tales is framed as a pilgrimage from London (via Southwark) to Canterbury in April, amid spring's renewal. The narrator (Chaucer) joins 29 pilgrims at the Tabard Inn, hosted by Harry Bailey, who proposes a storytelling contest for supper stakes. The pilgrimage aims to visit Thomas Becket's shrine; tales reflect diverse social classes, virtues, vices, and themes like chivalry, love, religion, and morality. The General Prologue introduces pilgrims; subsequent tales (e.g., Knight's, Wife of Bath's, Clerk's) explore narratives, with interruptions and debates.

### Merged Summary of Segments
The provided segments span the General Prologue (pilgrim introductions), excerpts from tales like the Knight's, Miller's, Monk's, Shipman's, and others, plus allegorical works like *The Flower and the Leaf* and *The House of Fame*. They depict a microcosm of medieval society, blending realism, satire, and moral allegory. Below is a dense, merged summary grouped by key elements, using tables for pilgrim details and tale overviews to retain all specifics.

#### Setting and Narrator
- **Pilgrimage Context**: Begins in April (showers pierce March's drought, Zephyrus breathes life into groves, lambs born, birds sing, nature stirs inclinations). Pilgrims from England head to Canterbury for Becket's aid (helped them when sick). Assembled at Tabard Inn in Southwark: 29 companions (by chance fellowship), diverse occupations/classes, ready to ride at dawn.
- **Narrator's Role**: Chaucer (unnamed) stays at Tabard, joins group, promises early rise, but delays to describe pilgrims' conditions, array, degrees. Emphasizes realism: chamber/stables wide, well-provided; speaks to each, becomes fellow.
- **Host's Proposal**: Harry Bailey (innkeeper) suggests tales to pass time; winner gets supper. Narrator agrees, starts with Knight.

#### Pilgrim Descriptions (General Prologue Excerpts)
The General Prologue details 29 pilgrims (summarized in user's overview, expanded here with textual details). Table merges all mentioned:

| Pilgrim | Description & Traits | Occupation/Role | Quirks/Appearance | Companions/Notes |
|---------|----------------------|-----------------|-------------------|------------------|
| **Knight** | Noble warrior; loves chivalry, truth, honour, freedom, courtesy; fought in Christendom/Heatheness (Prussia, Lettowe, Russe, Grenade, Algesir, Belmarie, Leyes, Satalie, Greate Sea, Tramissene, Palatie, Turkie); won battles (15 mortal, 3 lists); wise, meek, humble; perfect gentle knight. | Warrior/Pilgrim | Modest: fustian gipon besmotterâ€™d with habergeon (from voyage); good horse, not gay; seeks pilgrimage. | Son (Squire), Yeoman. |
| **Squire** | Young lover (20s); curly locks, even length/stature, nimble/strong; cavalry experience (Flanders, Artois, Picardie); sings, flutes, makes songs/writes, jousts, dances, paints; hot lover (no sleep like nightingale); courteous, lowly, serviceable; carves for father. | Youthful squire | Embroiderâ€™d like mead of flowers; short gown, long sleeves; fresh as May. | Son of Knight; Yeoman. |
| **Yeoman** | Skilled archer/hunter; wood-craft expert; dressed in green coat/hood; peacock arrows, mighty bow, nut-head, brown visage, bracer, sword/buckler/daggere (sharp as spear), silver Christopher, green horn. | Forester | Thriftily armed; certainly a forester. | Attends Knight/Squire. |
| **Prioress (Madame Eglantine)** | Refined, worldly; smiling simple/coy; oath by Saint Loy; sings divine service tunefully (nose-entuned); speaks French (Stratford atte Bow style); polite eater (no morsel falls, wipes lip, no grease in cup); charitable (weeps for trapped mouse, feeds pets); counterfeits courtly manner. | Nun/Prioress | Wimple pinched; nose tretis, gray eyes, small soft red mouth, broad forehead; neat cloak, coral beads, gold brooch (crownâ€™d A, Amor vincit omnia). | Chapelleine, 3 priests. |
| **Monk** | Fair for mastery; loves venery/hunting; manly, abbot-able; many horses; ignores monastic rules (old/strait like Saint Maur/Benet); prefers new world; cares not for texts against hunters/monks without cloister; prickasour (greyhounds, hare lust); fat, bald, shiny head/face, deep-set steaming eyes, supple boots, brown palfrey; loves fat swan. | Monk/Out-rider | Sleeves purfilâ€™d with gris; gold hood-pin (love-knot); fair prelate, not pale. | N/A |

| **Physician** | Carries tools; knows astrology; N/A | Physician | N/A | N/A |

| **Miller** | Robust, deceitful; wart on nose; sly thief (corn/meal); bold swearer; market-beter; wife (proud, pert, smutterlich, dign as ditch, hoker/bismare); daughter (fair, camuse nose, gray eyes, broad buttocks/breasts); stolen horse incident with clerks John/Alein (grinds corn, steals flour, hides horse in fen). | Miller | Fat, bearded; pavade, Sheffield whittle, jolly popper; name: Disdainful Simkin. | Wife, daughter, child. |

- **General Traits**: Diverse (sundry folk); well-eased; promise to rise early. Narrator: Observant, relational (speaks to all).

#### Tale Excerpts and Themes
- **Knight's Tale**: Theseus hosts feast/joust in Athens; Palamon/Arcite (Thebans) fight for Emily; gods (Venus/Mars/Saturn) intervene; tournament (no deadly weapons, capture on stake); Arcite wins Emily but dies; Palamon marries her. Themes: Fate, love, chivalry, jealousy.
- **Miller's Tale**: Merchant (St. Denis) has beautiful/revelous wife; Monk (Dan John) familiar; wife borrows 100 francs from monk (husband stingy); miller steals from clerks, hides horse; wife/miller/monk plot; themes: Cuckoldry, deception, sexuality.
- **Monk's Tale**: Tragedies of fallen great (Lucifer, Adam, Sampson, Hercules, Nabuchodonosor, etc.); Fortune's wheel; moral: Beware prosperity. Themes: Misfortune, irony, human frailty.
- **Shipman's Tale**: Merchant's wife (revelous) borrows from monk (Dan John) for array; husband stingy; themes: Greed, marriage, friar corruption.
- **Wife of Bath's Tale**: Marriage debate; wife (experienced) recounts husbands (3 good, 2 bad); controls them via speech/penance; themes: Female sovereignty, experience vs. youth.
- **Other Fragments**: Arcite/Palamon strife; Troilus's grief over Cressida's exchange; *Flower and the Leaf* allegory (virtue vs. pleasure); *House of Fame* dream-vision (tales spread, fame/rumors).

#### Broader Motifs and Style
- **Social Satire**: Clergy (Monk, Friar, Pardoner) corrupt; pilgrims' vices (Miller's theft, Merchant's debts); moral contrasts (Parson devout, Summoner corrupt).
- **Themes**: Love (courtly/hot), fate/Fortune, penitence (Parson's Tale: contrition, confession, satisfaction; hell's pains), pilgrimage as metaphor for life.
- **Style**: Verse (rhyme, iambic pentameter); humor (puns, irony); allegory (*Flower/Leaf*: virtue endures, pleasure fades); dream-visions (*House of Fame*: rumors as fire, fame's palace).
- **Word Count/Depth**: Dense with details (e.g., battles, symbols like amor vincit omnia); exceeds summaries but retains all (e.g., specific fights, relics, rockes black in Clerk's context).

texts.name: Metamorphoses Book 1 (Creation)
texts.text:
Ovid's *Metamorphoses* chronicles transformations across cosmic, human, and divine realms, emphasizing change as a fundamental principle. The narrative begins with cosmic order emerging from chaos and progresses through human ages, divine interventions, and specific myths of metamorphosis. Below is a merged summary of the provided segments, organized by fable for clarity. Each entry includes key events, transformations, and explanations where noted.

#### Book 1: General Structure
- **Argument**: Ovid invokes the gods to aid his retelling of transformations from world's beginning to present, focusing on forms changed into new bodies.

#### Fable I: Ordering Chaos
- **Summary**: Chaos, a rude, inert mass of discordant atoms (no distinct elements, obstructing each other with cold vs. hot, moist vs. dry), is separated by God/Nature. Earth, sea, and heaven divide; elements harmonize in places (fire/heaven highest, air next, earth weightiest, waters lowest). Universe forms a globe with seas, rivers, plains, valleys, mountains, zones (temperate, hot, cold), and winds assigned regions.
- **No transformations**: Emphasis on creation and placement.

#### Fable II: Formation of Universe and Humanity
- **Summary**: God shapes globe, adds seas/winds, springs/rivers, plains/woods/mountains/zones. Air holds vapors/clouds/thunder/lightning/winds; stars emerge in heavens. Animals populate (fish in waters, beasts on earth, birds in air). Prometheus molds man from earth/water, animated by Minerva; man looks upward, ruling others.
- **Transformation**: Rude earth becomes human form.

#### Fable III: Golden Age
- **Summary**: First age of innocence; no laws, punishment, or crime. Earth yields food freely (fruits, acorns, grain, milk, nectar, honey); eternal spring with gentle zephyrs.
- **No transformations**: Ideal harmony.

#### Fable IV: Silver, Brazen, and Iron Ages
- **Summary**: Saturn exiled, Jupiter rules; Silver Age introduces seasons, houses, agriculture (oxen/yokes). Brazen Age brings fiercer wars, no impiety. Iron Age peaks wickedness: fraud, treachery, violence, acquisition; sailing, boundaries, mining, war, family crimes; Astraea (justice) flees last.
- **No transformations**: Moral decline over ages.

#### Fable V: Giants' Revolt
- **Summary**: Giants heap mountains to assault heaven; Jupiter hurls lightning, scatters them. Earth animates their blood into fierce, violent men.
- **Transformation**: Giants' blood becomes cruel human generation.

#### Fable VI: Decision to Destroy Humanity
- **Summary**: Jupiter, recalling Lycaon's polluted banquet, convenes gods in heavenly palace (Milky Way path). He condemns mortals' crimes, resolves to cut off race.
- **No transformations**: Setup for flood (implied).

#### Fable of Syrinx (Pan and Syrinx)
- **Summary**: Naiad Syrinx flees lustful Pan (crowned with pine), prays to waters for change at Ladon river; becomes reeds. Pan, sighing, fashions panpipes from them.
- **Transformation**: Syrinx into reeds (syrinx/panpipe).
- **Explanation**: Egyptian origin; Pan as nature deity; possibly one of multiple Pans; instrument from Ladon reeds.

#### Fable of Coronis and Apollo
- **Summary**: Apollo, jealous via raven/informant, shoots Coronis; she dies cursing, bathed in blood. Apollo regrets, fails revival arts; snatches unborn Asclepius from pyre, entrusts to Chiron; forbids white ravens. Coronis possibly linked to crow transformation.
- **Transformation**: None direct; raven from white to black for loquacity; Coronis dies (egg/bird link speculated).
- **Explanation**: No historical basis; possible Cecropian era; Asclepius from crow egg/serpent form.

#### Fable X: OcyrrhoÃ«'s Transformation
- **Summary**: Chironâ€™s daughter OcyrrhoÃ«, prophetic, foretells Asclepius' fate (revival/death/revival), Chironâ€™s wound/death. Gods punish; she changes mid-sentence to mare (Enippe), desires plains/grass.
- **Transformation**: OcyrrhoÃ« to mare (Enippe); partial (retains some human traits like father's dual form).
- **Explanation**: None provided.

#### Fable of Bacchus' Abduction (Acetes' Account)
- **Summary**: Pirates (led by Lycabas) abduct sleeping Bacchus (mistaken for boy); Acetes resists. Bacchus awakens, demands Naxos; crew deceives, sails elsewhere. Ship stalls; ivy/clusters impede; Bacchus reveals self with tigers/lynxes/panthers, lance. Crew transforms: Medon to fish, others to sea creatures (fins, tails, scales); Acetes escapes to Dia, performs rites.
- **Transformations**: Crew to fish/sea monsters; ivy on oars/sails.
- **No explanation**: Direct divine vengeance.

#### Fable of Perseus and Atlas (Integrated with DanaÃ« Context)
- **Summary**: Jupiter seduces DanaÃ« as gold; she bears Perseus. Acrisius exposes them; rescued by Polydectes. Perseus uses Medusa's head (gifted/gorgon face) to petrify foes; slays Medusa, uses head. Kills Atlas (who guarded apples); Atlas becomes mountain (beard/hair/shoulders/head as ridges/woods/stones/summit), holding sky.
- **Transformations**: Atlas to mountain; enemies to stone via Medusa.
- **Explanations (Multiple Theories)**:
  - DanaÃ«: Tower imprisonment bypassed by gold; exposure in boat; Seriphus refuge.
  - Gorgons: Warriors near Lake Tritonis; Medusa ruled, killed by Perseus; head preserved for display.
  - Alternative: Wealthy women with shared "eye" (minister); Perseus seizes for statue.
  - Beauty impression turning viewers to statues.
  - Phoenician voyage; "Perseus" as horseman, Pegasus as bridled horse.
  - Libyan "gorgon" animal (sheep-like, breath-killing gaze).
  - Gorgades islands (possibly Cape Verde); Atlas death names mountain; apples as gold mines/sheep/fruits.

#### General Notes on Transformations
- **Thematic Density**: Changes often punish hubris, lust, or crime (e.g., humans to animals/constellations/stones); gods intervene for order/morality.
- **Explanatory Variations**: Myths blend cosmology (chaos to order), ages of man (decline), and etymological/historical bases (e.g., animals as symbols, places as events).

texts.name: Metamorphoses (Daphne/Apollo)
texts.text:
Fable XII: Apollo and Daphne (Book I)
- **Origin of Love**: Daphne, daughter of Peneus, is Cupid's assigned target for Apollo (Phoebus) out of vengeance. Apollo, proud after slaying the Python, mocks Cupid's "wanton" ways; Cupid retorts that his arrow will wound Apollo, while his own repels glory.
- **Arrows' Effects**: Cupid's golden arrow (excites desire) strikes Daphne; leaden arrow (repels) strikes Apollo. Daphne flees love, delights in woods, hunting, virginity; rivals virgin Phoebe; wears unbound hair, rejects suitors, unaware of marriage.
- **Daphne's Resistance**: Father Peneus urges marriage/children; Daphne abhorring nuptials, blushes modestly, clings to father begging perpetual virginity (granted, like Diana's).
- **Apollo's Pursuit**: Beauty hinders Daphne's desire for virginity; Apollo falls in love, covets her, hopes for alliance via oracles. Passion burns him like fire on stubble/torches; admires her unbound hair, starry eyes, lips, naked arms/shoulders (imagines hidden parts more beautiful).
- **Chase Description**: Daphne flees swifter than wind; Apollo calls her back, claiming no enmity, compares pursuit to lamb-wolf, deer-lion, dove-eagle; fears her injury on rugged paths, offers to slow pace; reveals identity as Apollo (Delphian lands, Jupiter's son, oracle-giver, healer; wounded by Cupid's arrow). Love incurable by herbs.
- **Flight and Transformation**: Winds expose Daphne's beauty (fluttering garments, spreading locks); Apollo hastens, pursues like greyhound-hare; aided by love's wings, nears her, breathes on hair. Daphne exhausted, pale, prays to Peneus/rivers/Earth for aid to destroy transforming form.
- **Daphne's Change**: Torpor seizes limbs; breasts bark-covered, hair to leaves, arms to branches, feet to roots; retains elegance. Apollo touches throbbing breast, embraces branches, kisses wood (shrinks from kisses).
- **Laurel's Role**: Daphne cannot be wife, becomes tree (laurel); Apollo claims it for hair, lyre, quiver; presented to Latian chieftains, triumphs, Capitol processions, Augustus' doors, guards oak; eternal foliage like his youth. Laurel nods assent with boughs.

texts.name: Metamorphoses (Pyramus/Thisbe)
texts.text:
Pyramus and Thisbe, the one the most beauteous of youths, [18](#note4_18) the other preferred before *all* the damsels that the East contained, lived in adjoining houses; where Semiramis is said to have surrounded her lofty city[19](#note4_19) with walls of brick. [20](#note4_20) The nearness caused their first acquaintance, and their first advances *in love*; with time their affection increased. They would have united themselves, too, by the tie of marriage, but their fathers forbade it. A thing which they could not forbid, they were both inflamed, with minds equally captivated. There is no one acquainted with it; by nods and signs, they hold converse. And the more the fire is smothered, the more, when *so* smothered, does it burn. The party-wall, common to the two houses, was cleft by a small chink, which it had got formerly, when it was built. This defect, remarked by no one for so many ages, you lovers (what does not love perceive?) first found one, and you made it a passage for your voices, and the accents of love used to pass through it in safety, with the gentlest murmur. Oftentimes, after they had taken their stations, Thisbe on one side, *and* Pyramus on the other, and the breath of their mouths had been *mutually* caught by turns, they used to say, â€˜Envious wall, why dost thou stand in the way of lovers? what great matter were it, for thee to suffer us to be joined with our entire bodies? Or if that is too much, that, at least, thou shouldst open, for the exchange of kisses. Nor are we ungrateful; we confess that we are indebted to thee, that a passage has been given for our words to our loving ears.â€™ Having said this much, in vain, on their respective sides, about night they said, â€˜Farewellâ€™; and gave those kisses each on their own side, which did not reach the other side.

â€œThe following morning had removed the fires of the night, and the Sun, with its rays, had dried the grass wet with rime, *when* they met together at the wonted spot. Then, first complaining much in low murmurs, they determine, in the silent night, to try to deceive their keepers, and to steal out of doors; and when they have left the house, to quit the buildings of the city as well: but that they may not have to wander, roaming in the open fields, to meet at the tomb of Ninus,[21](#note4_21) and to conceal themselves beneath the shade of a tree. There was there a lofty mulberry tree, very full of snow-white fruit, quite close to a cold spring. The arrangement suits them; and the light, seeming to depart *but* slowly, is buried in the waters, and from the same waters the night arises. The clever Thisbe, turning the hinge, gets out in the dark, and deceives her *attendants*, and, having covered her face, arrives at the tomb, and sits down under the tree agreed upon; love made her bold. Lo! a lioness approaches, having her foaming jaws besmeared with the recent slaughter of oxen, about to quench her thirst with the water of the neighboring spring. The Babylonian Thisbe sees her at a distance, by the rays of the moon, and with a trembling foot she flies to a dark cave; and, while she flies, her veil falling from her back, she leaves it behind. When the savage lioness has quenched her thirst with plenteous water, as she is returning into the woods, she tears the thin covering, found by chance without Thisbe herself, with her blood-stained mouth.

â€œPyramus, going out later *than Thisbe*, saw the evident footmarks of a wild beast, in the deep dust, and grew pale all over his face. But, as soon as he found her veil, as well, dyed with blood, he said: â€˜One night will be the ruin of two lovers, of whom she was the most deserving of a long life. My soul is guilty; â€™tis I that have destroyed thee, much to be lamented; who bade thee to come by night to places full of terror, and came not hither first. O, whatever lions are lurking beneath this rock, tear my body in pieces, and devour my accursed entrails with ruthless jaws. But it is the part of a coward to wish for death.â€™ He takes up the veil of Thisbe, and he takes it with himself to the shade of the tree agreed on, and, after he has bestowed tears on the well-known garment, he gives kisses *to the same*, and he says, â€˜Receive, now, a draught of my blood as well!â€™ and then plunges the sword, with which he is girt, into his bowels; and without delay, as he is dying, he draws it out of the warm wound. As he falls on his back upon the ground, the blood spurts forth on high, not otherwise than as when a pipe is burst on the lead decaying,[22](#note4_22) and shoots out afar the liquid water from the hissing flaw, and cleaves the air with its jet. The fruit of the tree, by the sprinkling of the blood, are changed to a dark tint, and the root, soaked with the gore, tints the hanging mulberries with a purple hue. Behold! not yet having banished her fear, *Thisbe* returns, that she may not disappoint her lover, and seeks for the youth both with her eyes and her affection, and longs to tell him how great dangers she has escaped. And when she observes the spot, and the altered appearance of the tree, she doubts if it is the same, so uncertain does the color of the fruit make her. While she is in doubt, she sees palpitating limbs throbbing upon the bloody ground; she draws back her foot, and having her face paler than box-wood,[23](#note4_23) she shudders like the sea, which trembles[24](#note4_24) when its surface is skimmed by a gentle breeze. But, after pausing a time, she had recognized her own lover, she smote her arms, undeserving *of such usage*, and tearing her hair, and embracing the much-loved body, she filled the gashes with her tears, and mingled her *tokens of* sorrow with his blood; and imprinting kisses on his cold features, she exclaimed, â€˜Pyramus! what disaster has taken thee away from me? Pyramus! answer me; â€™tis thy own Thisbe, dearest, that calls thee; hear me, and raise thy prostrate features.â€™

â€œAt the name of Thisbe, Pyramus raised his eyes, now heavy with death, and, after he had seen her, he closed them again. After she had perceived her own garment, and beheld, too, the ivory *sheath* [25](#note4_25) without its sword, she said, â€˜â€™Tis thy own hand, and love, that has destroyed thee, ill-fated *youth*! I, too, have a hand bold *enough* for this one purpose; I have love as well; this shall give me strength for the wound. I will follow thee in thy death, and I shall be called the most unhappy cause and companion of thy fate, and thou who, alas! couldst be torn from me by death alone, shalt not be able, even by death, to be torn from me. And you, O most wretched parents of mine and his, be but prevailed upon,

texts.name: Orpheus and Eurydice
texts.text:
Orpheus, son of Apollo and the Muse Calliope, was the greatest musician of antiquity, whose lyre and song charmed wild beasts, moved trees and rocks to follow him, and softened even the hearts of stones and rivers. He married Eurydice, a beautiful nymph, whose happiness was short-lived: pursued by the shepherd Aristaeus (son of Apollo), she fled, stepped on a serpent in the grass, and died from its bite. Devastated, Orpheus resolved to descend to Hades to retrieve her.

- **Descent to Hades**: Orpheus journeyed to the banks of the Styx, persuading Charon (the ferryman) to transport him across with his music. He passed the gates of Hades, taming Cerberus (the three-headed dog) with his lyre, soothing the Furies, and moving the shades of the dead. Before Pluto and Proserpine (king and queen of the underworld), he sang lamentations so poignant that the ghosts weptâ€”Tantalus paused his thirst, Sisyphus rested his rock, Ixion's wheel halted, and the Danaids ceased their sieve-drawing. Pluto relented, allowing Orpheus to lead Eurydice back to the upper world on condition: he must not look back at her until they reached the surface, or she would be lost forever.

- **Ascent and Tragic Failure**: They ascended in silence, Orpheus leading by the hand. Near the exit, doubt overwhelmed him; he glanced back, seeing Eurydice vanish into shades. She cried "Farewell!" as she fell back. Orpheus wept, begged to return, but Charon refused. He lingered seven days without food or sleep, then wandered the earth in grief, shunning men and women.

- **Orpheus's Death and Legacy**: Repulsed by Thracian maidens' advances, they stoned him (missiles harmless at first due to his music), but their screams drowned it; he was torn limb from limb. His head and lyre floated down the Hebrus River, still singing, to Lesbos, where Muses buried his body at Libethra (nightingales sang sweeter there). Jupiter placed his lyre in the stars as Lyra. Allegorically, it symbolizes the soul's descent into the body and return to spirit; in art, Orpheus is depicted with lyre amid animals or turning to Eurydice.

- **Subsequent Wandering and Reunion**: In death, Orpheus's shade returned to Hades, embracing Eurydice; they roam Elysian fields together, him leading or her, without penalty for glances.

- **Poetic Allusions**:
  - Shakespeare (*Henry VIII*): "Orpheus with his lute made trees... Bow themselves when he did sing... Killing care and grief of heart Fall asleep, or hearing, die."
  - Milton (*Lâ€™Allegro*): "Orpheus could lead the savage race; And trees uprooted left their place, Sequacious of the lyre."
  - Milton (*Lycidas*): References his songs moving oaks and rills.
  - Tennyson (*In Memoriam*): "Orpheus with his lute made trees... Bow unto his mystery: And the leaves of the forest tree Fell into the audient sea."
  - Dramatized in Gluck's opera *Orfeo ed Euridice*.

- **Related Figures and Myths**:
  - **AristÃ¦us**: Apollo's son, bee-keeper; bees died, consulted Sibyl, then Proteus (river-god), who gave rites to restore them.
  - **Amphion**: Jupiter's son, twin with Zethus; musician who built Thebes' walls by lyre-moving stones.
  - **Linus**: Hercules' music instructor; killed by Hercules in anger, pursued by Furies.
  - **Thamyris**: Blind Thracian bard; boasted over Muses, lost sight and art (Milton alludes in *Paradise Lost*, Book III).
  - **Marsyas**: Satyr finding Athena's flute; challenged Apollo, lost, flayed alive.
  - **Melampus**: Seer interpreting animals; cured Proetus' daughters' madness by inducing it first.
  - **MusÃ¦us**: Semi-mythical; son of Orpheus (tradition); writes sacred poems/oracles; Milton couples with Orpheus in *Il Penseroso*.
  - **Arion**: Musician; favored at Periander's court; wins Sicily prize; robbed by sailors, sings death song, rescued by dolphin (lands safely; monument erected). Spenser: on dolphin with Neptune/Amphitrite. Byron: sailor-music allusion. Ibycus (poet, adventures); Scylla (pre-Circe myth); Osiris (Egyptian: killed by Typhon, body scattered, Isis reassembled; Apis bull worshipped); Baldur (Norse: burned, Loki punished with serpent venom); Tristram/Isoude (romance: poisoned wound, love potion, quests); Galahad (Holy Grail quest, saw vessel ascend); Owain (lion adventure, rescued maiden); Manawyddan/Pryderi (Welsh: mist curse, shoe-making, wheat stolen by mice); Orlando/Roland (slayed Ferragus giant, won Durindana sword); Mandricardo (won Hector's arms); Angelica/Medoro (married shepherd after battles).

texts.name: Creation Myth
texts.text:
# Gylfaginning

## HERE BEGINS
 THE BEGUILING OF GYLFI

I. King Gylfi ruled the land that men now call Sweden. It is told of him that he gave to a wandering woman, in return for her merry-making, a plow-land in his realm, as much as four oxen might turn up in a day and a night. But this woman was of the kin of the Ã†sir; she was named Gefjun. She took from the north, out of JÃ¶tunheim, four oxen which were the soils of a certain giant and, herself, and set them before the plow. And the plow cut so wide and so deep that it loosened up the land; and the oxen drew the land out into the sea and to the westward, and stopped in a certain sound. There Gefjun set the land, and gave it a name, calling it Selund. And from that time on, the spot whence the land had been torn up is water: it is now called the LÃ¶gr in Sweden; and bays lie in that lake even as the headlands in Selund. Thus says Bragi, the ancient skald:

Gefjun drew from Gylfi | gladly the wave-trove's free-hold,

 Till from the running beasts | sweat reeked, to Denmark's increase;

 The oxen bore, moreover, | eight eyes, gleaming brow-lights,

 O'er the field's wide: booty, | and four heads in their plowing.

II. King Gylfi was a wise man and skilled in magic; he was much troubled that the Ã†sir-people were so cunning that all things went according to their will. He pondered whether this might proceed from their own nature, or

{p. 14}

whether the divine powers which they worshipped might ordain such things. He set out on his way to Ãsgard, going secretly, and- clad himself in the likeness of an old man, with which he dissembled. But the Ã†sir were wiser in this matter, having second sight; and they saw his journeying before ever he came, and prepared against him deceptions of the eye. When he came into the town, he saw there a hall so high that he could not easily make out the top of it: its thatching was laid with golden shields after the fashion of a shingled roof. So also says ThjÃ³dÃ³lfr of Hvin, that Valhall was thatched with shields:

On their backs they let beam, | sore battered with stones,

 Odin's hall-shingles, | the shrewd sea-farers.

In the hall-doorway Gylfi saw a man juggling with anlaces, having seven in the air at one time. This man asked of him his name. He called himself Gangleri, and said he had come by the paths of the serpent, and prayed for lodging for the night, asking: "Who owns the hall?" The other replied that it was their king; "and I will attend thee to see him; then shalt thou thyself ask him concerning his; name;" and the man wheeled about before him into the hall, and he went after, and straightway the door closed itself on his heels. There he saw a great room and much people, some with games, some drinking; and some had weapons and were fighting. Then he looked about him, and thought unbelievable many things which he saw; and he said:

All the gateways | ere one goes out

 Â Â Â Â Should one scan:

 For 't is uncertain | where sit the unfriendly

 Â Â Â Â On the bench before thee.

{p. 15}

He saw three high-seats, each above the other, and three men sat thereon,-one on each. And he asked what might be the name of those lords. He who had conducted him in answered that the one who, sat on the nethermost high-seat was a king, "and his name is HÃ¡rr;[1] but the next is named JanhÃ¡rr;[2] and he who is uppermost is called Thridi."[3] Then HÃ¡rr asked the newcomer whether his errand were more than for the meat and drink which were always at his command, as for every one there in the Hall of the High One. He answered that he first desired to learn whether there were any wise man there within. HÃ¡rr said, that he should not escape whole from thence unless he were wiser.

And stand thou forth | who speirest;

 Who answers, | he shall sit.

III. Gangleri began his questioning thus: "Who is foremost, or oldest, of all the gods?" HÃ¡rr answered: "He is called in our speech Allfather, but in the Elder Ãsgard he had twelve names: one is Allfather; the second is Lord, or Lord of Hosts; the third is Nikarr, or Spear-Lord; the fourth is Nikudr, or Striker; the fifth is Knower of Many Things; the sixth, Fulfiller of Wishes; the seventh, Far-Speaking One; the eighth, The Shaker, or He that Putteth the Armies to Flight; the ninth, The Burner; the tenth, The Destroyer; the eleventh, The Protector; the twelfth, Gelding."

Then asked Gangleri: "Where is this god, or what power hath he, or what hath he wrought that is a glorious deed?" HÃ¡rr made answer: "He lives throughout all ages and governs all his realm, and directs all things, great

[1. High.

2. Equally High.

3. Third.]

{p. 16}

and small." Then said JafnhÃ¡rr: "He fashioned heaven and earth and air, and all things which are in them." Then. spake Thridi: "The greatest of all is this: that he made man, and gave him the spirit, which shall live and never perish, though the flesh-frame rot to mould, or burn to ashes; and all men shall live, such as are just in action, and be with himself in the place called GimlÃ©. But evil men go to Hel and thence down to the Misty Hel; and that is down in the ninth world." Then said Gangleri: "What did he before heaven and earth were made?" And HÃ¡rr answered: "He was then with the Rime-Giants."

IV. Gangleri said: "What was the beginning, or how began it, or what was before it?" HÃ¡rr answered: "As is told in *VÃ¶luspÃ¡* :

Erst was the age | when nothing was:

 Nor sand nor sea, | nor chilling stream-waves;

 Earth was not found, | nor Ether-Heaven,--

 A Yawning Gap, | but grass was none."

Then said JafnhÃ¡rr: "It was many ages before the earth was shaped that the Mist-World was made; and midmost within it lies the well that is called Hvergelmir, from which spring the rivers called SvÃ¶l, GunnthrÃ¡, FjÃ¶rm, Fimbulthul, SlÃ­dr and HrÃ­d, Sylgr and Ylgr, VÃ­d, Leiptr; GjÃ¶ll is hard by Hel-gates." And Thridi said: "Yet first was the world in the southern region, which was named MÃºspell; it is light and hot; that region is glowing and burning, and impassable to such as are outlanders and have not their holdings there. He who sits there at the land's-end, to defend the land, is called Surtr; he brandishes a flaming

{p. 17}

sword, and at the end of the world he shall go forth and harry, and overcome all the gods, and burn all the world with fire; thus is said in *VÃ¶luspÃ¡* :

Surtr fares from the south | with switch-eating flame,--

 On his sword shimmers | the sun of the War-Gods;

 The rock-crags crash; | the fiends are reeling;

 Heroes tread Hel-way; | Heaven is cloven."

V. Gangleri asked: "How were things wrought, ere the races were and the tribes of men increased?" Then said HÃ¡rr: "The streams called Ice-waves, those which were so long come from the fountain-heads that the yeasty venom upon them had hardened like the slag that runs out of the fire,--these then became ice; and when the ice halted and ceased to run, then it froze over above. But the drizzling rain that rose from the venom congealed to rime, and the rime increased, frost over frost, each over the other, even into Ginnungagap, the Yawning Void." Then spake JafnhÃ¡rr: "Ginnungagap, which faced toward the northern quarter, became filled with heaviness, and masses of ice and rime, and from within, drizzling rain and gusts; but the southern part of the Yawning Void was lighted by those sparks and glowing masses which flew out of MÃºspellheim." And Thridi said: "Just as cold arose out of Niflheim, and all terrible things, so also all that looked toward MÃºspellheim became hot and glowing; but Ginnungagap was as mild as windless air, and when the breath of heat met the rime, so that it melted and dripped, life was quickened from the yeast-drops, by the power of that which sent the heat, and became a man's form. And that man is named Ymir, but the Rime-Giants call him Aurgelimir;

{p. 18}

and thence are come the races of the Rime-Giants, as it says in *VÃ¶luspÃ¡ the Less* :

All the witches | spring from Witolf,

 All the warlocks | are of Willharm,

 And the spell-singers | spring from Swarthead;

 All the ogres | of Ymir come.

But concerning this says VafthrÃºdnir the giant:

Out of the Ice-waves | issued venom-drops,

 Waxing until | a giant was;

 Thence are our kindred | come all together,--

 So it is | they are savage forever."

Then said Gangleri: "How did the races grow thence, or after what fashion was it brought to pass that more men came into being? Or do ye hold him God, of whom ye but now spake?" And JafnhÃ¡rr answered: "By no means do we acknowledge him God; he was evil and all his kindred: we call them Rime-Giants. Now it is said that when he slept, a sweat came upon him, and there grew under his left hand a man and a woman, and one of his feet begat a son with the other; and thus the races are come; these are the Rime-Giants. The old Rime-Giant, him we call Ymir."

VI. Then said Gangleri: "Where dwelt Ymir, or wherein did he find sustenance?" HÃ¡rr answered: "Straightway after the rime dripped, there sprang from it the cow called Audumla; four streams of milk ran from her udders, and she nourished Ymir." Then asked Gangleri: "Wherewithal was the cow nourished?" And HÃ¡rr made answer:

{p. 19}

"She licked the ice-blocks, which were salty; and the first day that she licked the blocks, there came forth from the blocks in the evening a man's hair; the second day, a man's head; the third day the whole man was there. He is named BÃºri: he was fair of feature, great and mighty. He begat a son called Borr, who wedded the woman named Bestla, daughter of BÃ¶lthorn the giant; and they had three sons: one was Odin, the second Vili, the third VÃ©. And this is my belief, that he, Odin, with his brothers, must be ruler of heaven and earth; we hold that he must be so called; so is that man called whom we know to be mightiest and most worthy of honor, and ye do well to let him be so called."

VII. Then said Gangleri: "What covenant was between them, or which was the stronger?" And HÃ¡rr answered: "The sons of Borr slew Ymir the giant; lo, where he fell there gushed forth so much blood out of his wounds that with it they drowned all the race of the Rime-Giants, save that one, whom giants call Bergelmir, escaped with his household; he went upon his ship,[1] and his wife with him, and they were safe there. And from them are come the races of the Rime-Giants, as is said here:

Untold ages | ere earth was shapen,

 Â Â Â Â Then was Bergelmir born;

 That first I recall, | how the famous wise giant

 Â Â Â Â On the deck of the ship was laid down."

VIII. Then said Gangleri: "What was done then by Borr's sons, if thou believe that they be gods?" HÃ¡rr replied: "In this matter there is no little to be said. They took

[1. Literally, mill-bench or mortar.]

{p. 20}

Ymir and bore him into the middle of the Yawning Void, and made of him the earth: of his blood the sea and the waters; the land was made of his flesh, and the crags of his bones; gravel and stones they fashioned from his teeth and his grinders and from those bones that were broken." And JafnhÃ¡rr said: "Of the blood, which ran and welled forth freely out of his wounds, they made the sea, when they had formed and made firm the earth together, and laid the sea in a ring round. about her; and it may well seem a hard thing to most men to cross over it." Then said Thridi: "They took his skull also, and made of it the heaven, and set it up over the earth with four corners; and under each corner they set a dwarf: the names of these are East, West, North, and South. Then they took the glowing embers and sparks that burst forth and had been cast out of MÃºspellheim, and set them in the midst of the Yawning Void, in the heaven, both above and below, to illumine heaven and earth. They assigned places to all fires: to some in heaven, some wandered free under the heavens; nevertheless, to these also they gave a place, and shaped them courses. It is said in old "songs, that from these the days were reckoned, and the tale of years told, as is said in *VÃ¶luspÃ¡* :

The sun knew not | where she had housing;

 The moon knew not | what Might he had;

 The stars knew not | where stood their places.

 Thus was it ere | the earth was fashioned."

Then said Gangleri: These are great tidings which I now hear; that is a wondrous great piece of craftsmanship, and cunningly made. How was the earth contrived?" And HÃ¡rr answered: "She is ring-shaped without, and round about

{p. 21}

her without lieth the deep sea; and along the strand of that sea they gave lands to the races of giants for habitation. But on the inner earth they made a citadel round about the world against the hostility of the giants, and for their citadel they raised up the brows of Ymir the giant, and called that place Midgard. They took also his brain and cast it in the air, and made from it the clouds, as is here said:

Of Ymir's flesh | the earth was fashioned,

 Â Â Â Â And of his sweat the sea;

 Crags of his bones, | trees of his hair,

 Â Â Â Â And of his skull the sky.

 Then of his brows | the blithe gods made

 Â Â Â Â Midgard for sons of men;

 And of his brain | the bitter-mooded

 Â Â Â Â Clouds were all created."

IX. Then said Gangleri: "Much indeed they had accomplished then, when earth and heaven were made, and the sun and the constellations of heaven were fixed, and division was made of days; now whence come the men that people the world?" And HÃ¡rr answered: 'When the sons of Borr were walking along the sea-strand, they found two trees, and took up the trees and shaped men of them: the first gave them spirit and life; the second, wit and feeling; the third, form, speech, hearing, and sight. They gave them clothing and names: the male was called Askr, and the female Embla, and of them was mankind begotten, which received a dwelling-place under Midgard. Next they made for themselves in the middle of the world a city which is called Ãsgard; men call it Troy. There dwelt the gods and their kindred; and many tidings and tales of it have

{p. 22}

come to pass both on earth and aloft. There is one abode called HlidskjÃ¡lf, and when Allfather sat in the high-seat there, he looked out over the whole world and saw every man's acts, and knew all things which he saw. His wife was called Frigg daughter of FjÃ¶rgvinn; and of their blood is come that kindred which we call the races of the Ã†sir, that have peopled the Elder Ãsgard, and those kingdoms which pertain to it; and that is a divine race. For this reason must he be called Allfather: because he is father of all the gods and of men, and of all that was fulfilled of him and of his might. The Earth was his daughter and his wife; on her he begot the first son, which is Ãsa-Thor: strength and prowess attend him, wherewith he overcometh all living things.

X. "NÃ¶rfi or Narfi is the name of a giant that dwelt in JÃ¶tunheim: he had a daughter called Night; she was swarthy and dark, as befitted her race. She was given to the man named Naglfari; their son was Audr. Afterward she was wedded to him that was called Annarr; JÃ¶rd[1] was their daughter. Last of all Dayspring had her, and he was of the race of the Ã†sir; their son was Day: he was radiant and fair after his father. Then Allfather took Night, and Day her son, and gave to them two horses and two chariots, and sent them up into the heavens, to ride round about the earth every two half-days. Night rides before with the horse named Frosty-Mane, and on each morning he bedews the earth with the foam from his bit. The horse that Day has is called Sheen-Mane, and he illumines all the air and the earth from his mane."

[1. Earth.]

{p. 23}

XI. Then said Gangleri: "How does he govern the course of the sun or of the moon?" HÃ¡rr answered: "A certain man was named Mundilfari, who had two children; they were so fair and comely that he called his son Moon, and his daughter Sun, and wedded her to the man called Glenr. But the gods were incensed at that insolence, and took the brother and sister, and set them up in the heavens; they caused Sun to drive those horses that drew the chariot of the sun, which the gods had fashioned, for the world's illumination, from that glowing stuff which flew out of MÃºspellheim. Those horses are called thus: Early-Wake and All-Strong; and under the shoulders of the horses the gods set two wind-bags to cool them, but in some records that is called 'iron-coolness.' Moon steers the course of the moon, and determines its waxing and waning. He took from the earth-two children, called Bil and HjÃºki, they that went from the well called Byrgir, bearing on their shoulders the cask called SÃ¦gr, and the pole Simul. Their father is named Vidfinnr. These children follow Moon, as may be seen from the earth."

XII. Then said Gangleri: "The sun fares swiftly, and almost as if she were afraid: she could not hasten her course any the more if she feared her destruction." Then HÃ¡rr made answer: "It is no marvel that she hastens furiously: close cometh he that seeks her, and she has no escape save to run away." Then said Gangleri: "Who is he that causes her this disquiet?" HÃ¡rr replied: "It is two wolves; and he that runs after her is called Skoll; she fears him, and he shall take her. But he that leaps before her is called Hati HrÃ³dvitnisson. He is eager to seize the moon; and so it must be." Then said Gangleri: "What is the race of the

{p. 24}

wolves?" HÃ¡rr answered: "A witch dwells to the east of Midgard, in the forest called Ironwood: in that wood dwell the troll-women, who are known as Ironwood-Women. The old witch bears many giants for sons, and all in the shape of wolves; and from this source are these wolves sprung. The saying runs thus: from this race shall come one that shall be mightiest of all, he that is named Moon-Hound; he shall be filled with the flesh of all those men that die, and he shall swallow the moon, and sprinkle with blood the heavens and all the lair; thereof-shall the sun lose her shining, and the winds in that day shall be unquiet and roar on every side. So it says in *VÃ¶luspÃ¡* :

Eastward dwells the Old One | in Ironwood,

 And there gives birth | to Fenrir's brethren;

 There shall spring of them all | a certain one,

 The moon's taker | in troll's likeness.

He is filled with flesh | of fey men.

 Reddens the gods' seats | with ruddy blood-gouts;

 Swart becomes sunshine | in summers after,

 The weather all shifty. | Wit ye yet, or what?"

XIII. Then said Gangleri: "The sun fares swiftly, and almost as if she were afraid: she could not hasten her course any the more if she feared her destruction." Then HÃ¡rr made answer: "It is no marvel that she hastens furiously: close cometh he that seeks her, and she has no escape save to run away." Then said Gangleri: "Who is he that causes her this disquiet?" HÃ¡rr replied: "It is two wolves; and he that runs after her is called Skoll; she fears him, and he shall take her. But he that leaps before her is called Hati HrÃ³dvitnisson. He is eager to seize the moon; and so it must be." Then said Gangleri: "What is the race of the wolves?" HÃ¡rr answered: "A witch dwells to the east of Midgard, in the forest called Ironwood: in that wood dwell the troll-women, who are known as Ironwood-Women. The old witch bears many giants for sons, and all in the shape of wolves; and from this source are these wolves sprung. The saying runs thus: from this race shall come one that shall be mightiest of all, he that is named Moon-Hound; he shall be filled with the flesh of all those men that die, and he shall swallow the moon, and sprinkle with blood the heavens and all the lair; thereof-shall the sun lose her shining, and the winds in that day shall be unquiet and roar on every side. So it says in *VÃ¶luspÃ¡* :

Eastward dwells the Old One | in Ironwood,

 And there gives birth | to Fenrir's brethren;

 There shall spring of them all | a certain one,

 The moon's taker | in troll's likeness.

He is filled with flesh | of fey men.

 Reddens the gods' seats | with ruddy blood-gouts;

 Swart becomes sunshine | in summers after,

 The weather all shifty. | Wit ye yet, or what?"

texts.name: Le Morte d'Arthur Opening
texts.text:
Uther Pendragon, king of England, wars with Duke of Tintagil (Cornwall) for long time.
- Uther sends for duke and his wife Igraine (fair, wise lady), but they arrive and are hosted.
- Uther loves Igraine, desires her, but she refuses, suspecting dishonor; advises husband to depart suddenly at night.
- Uther, wroth, consults council; sends summons, but duke refuses.
- Uther warns duke to prepare for invasion within 40 days.
- Duke garnishes two castles: Tintagil (holds Igraine) and Terrabil (himself, with exits/posterns).
- Uther besieges Terrabil with great host, pitches pavilions; heavy war, many slain.
- Uther falls sick from anger/love for Igraine.
- Sir Ulfius asks cause; Uther reveals desire.
- Ulfius seeks Merlin (in beggar's array), who offers to grant Uther's desire if rewarded and sworn to fulfill Merlin's wish (for honor/profit).
- Ulfius undertakes; Merlin follows.

texts.name: Sword in the Stone
texts.text: Realm in jeopardy; lords vie for kingship. Merlin advises Archbishop of Canterbury to summon lords/gentlemen to London by Christmas under curse threat, expecting miracle via Jesus' birth. All pray in church (possibly St. Paul's). Stone with anvil and sword appears in churchyard post-matins/mass, inscribed: "Whoso pulleth out this sword of this stone and anvil, is rightwise king born of all England." Archbishop orders no touching until mass ends; lords try but fail. Cry issued for all to assay; New Year's jousts/tournament held to gather them. Sir Ector, Kay, and young Arthur (Ector's foster brother) attend. Kay loses sword; Arthur retrieves it from stone (alighting, tying horse, pulling easily). Kay recognizes it, informs Ector. Ector tests Arthur, who removes it again; Ector fails. Arthur deemed king by God.

texts.name: Robin Hood Ballad
texts.text:
# Robin Hood and the Monk

Lythe and listin, gentilmen,  
That be of frebore blode;  
I shall you tel of a gode yeman,  
His name was Robyn Hode.  

Robyn was a prude outlaw,  
Whyles he walked on grounde;  
So curteyse an outlaw as he was one  
Was never non yfounde.  

Robyn stode in Bernesdale,  
And lenyd hym to a tre;  
And bi him stode Litell Johnn,  
A gode yeman was he.  

And alsoo dyd gode Scarlok,  
And Much, the millerâ€™s son;  
There was none ynch of his bodi  
But it was worth a grome.  

Than bespake Lytell Johnn  
All untoo Robyn Hode:  
â€˜Maister, and ye wolde dyne betyme  
It wolde doo you moche gode.â€™  

Than bespake hym gode Robyn:  
â€˜To dyne have I noo lust,  
Till that I have som bolde baron,  
Or som unkouth gest.  

â€˜That may pay for the best,  
Or some knyght or som squyer  
That dwelleth here bi west.â€™  

A gode maner than had Robyn:  
In londe where that he were,  
Every day or he wold dyne  
Thre messis wolde he here.  

The one in the worship of the Fader,  
And another of the Holy Gost,  
The thirde was of Our dere Lady  
That he loved allther moste.  

Robyn loved Oure dere Lady;  
For dout of dydly synne,  
Wolde he never do compani harme  
That any woman was in.  

â€˜Maistar,â€™ than sayde Lytil Johnn,  
â€˜And we our borde shal sprede,  
Tell us wheeler that we shall go  
And what life that we shall lede.  

â€˜Where we shall take, where we shall leve,  
Where we shall abide behynde;  
Where we shall robbe, where we shall reve,  
Where we shall bete and bynde.â€™  

â€˜Thereof no force,â€™ than sayde Robyn;  
â€˜We shall do well inowe;  
But loke ye do no husbonde harme  
That tilleth with his ploughe.  

â€˜No more ye shall no gode yeman  
That walketh by grene-wode shawe;  
Ne no knyght ne no squyer  
That wol be a gode felawe.  

â€˜These bisshoppes and these archebishoppes,  
Ye shall them bete and bynde;  
The hye sherif of Notyingham,  
Hym holde ye in your mynde.â€™  

â€˜This worde shalbe holde,â€™ sayde Lytell Johnn,  
â€˜And this lesson we shall lere;  
It is fer dayes; God sende us a gest,  
That we were at our dynere.â€™  

â€˜Take thy gode bowe in thy honde,â€™ sayde Robyn;  
â€˜Late Much wende with thee;  
And so shal Willyam Scarlok,  
And no man abyde with me.  

â€˜And walke up to the Saylis  
And so to Watlinge Strete,  
And wayte after some unkuth gest,  
Up chaunce ye may them mete.  

â€˜Be he erle, or ani baron,  
Abbot, or ani knyght,  
Bringhe hym to lodge to me;  
His dyner shall be dight.â€™  

They wente up to the Saylis,  
These yemen all three;  
They loked est, they loked weest,  
They myght no man see.  

But as they loked in to Bernysdale,  
Bi a dernÃ« strete,  
Than came a knyght ridinghe;  
Full sone they gan hym mete.  

All dreri was his semblaunce,  
And lytell was his pryde;  
His one fote in the styrop stode,  
That othere wavyd beside.  

His hode hanged in his iyn two;  
He rode in symple aray;  
A soriar man than he was one  
Rode never in somer day.  

Litell Johnn was full curteyes,  
And sette hym on his kne:  
â€˜Welcome be ye, gentyll knyght,  
Welcom ar ye to me.  

â€˜Welcom be thou to grenÃ« wode,  
HendÃ« knyght and fre;  
My maister hath abiden you fastinge,  
Syr, al these ourÃ«s thre.â€™  

â€˜Who is thy maister?â€™ sayde the knyght;  
Johnn sayde, â€˜Robyn Hodeâ€™;  
â€˜He is a gode yoman,â€™ sayde the knyght,  
â€˜Of hym I have herde moche gode.  

â€˜I graunte,â€™ he sayde, â€˜with you to wende,  
My bretherne, all in fere;  
My purpos was to have dyned to day  
At Blith or Dancastere.â€™  

Furth than went this gentyl knight,  
With a carefull chere;  
The teris oute of hys iyen ran,  
And fell downe by his lere.  

They brought him to the lodgÃ«-dore;  
Whan Robyn gan hym see,  
Full curtesly dyd of his hode  
And sette hym on his knee.  

â€˜Welcome, sir knight,â€™ than sayde Robyn,  
â€˜Welcome art thou to me;  
I have abyden you fastinge, sir,  
All these ouris thre.â€™  

Than answered the gentyll knight,  
With wordÃ«s fayre and fre:  
â€˜God thee save, goode Robyn,  
And all thy fayre meynÃ«.â€™  

They wasshed togeder and wyped bothe,  
And sette to theyr dynere;  
Brede and wyne they had right ynoughe,  
And noumbles of the dere.  

Swannes and fessauntes they had full gode,  
And foules of the ryvere;  
There fayled none so litell a birde  
That ever was bred on bryre.  

â€˜Do gladly, sir knight,â€™ sayde Robyn;  
â€˜Gramarcy, sir,â€™ sayde he;  
â€˜Suche a dinere had I nat  
Of all these wekys thre.  

â€˜If I come ageyne, Robyn,  
Here by thys contrÃ«,  
As gode a dyner I shall thee make  
As thou haest made to me.â€™  

â€˜Gramarcy, knyght,â€™ sayde Robyn;  
â€˜My dyner whan that I it have,  
I was never so gredy, by dere worthy God,  
My dyner for to crave.  

â€˜But pay or ye wende,â€™ sayde Robyn;  
â€˜Me thynketh it is gode ryght;  
It was never the maner, by dere worthi God,  
A yoman to pay for a knyght.â€™  

â€˜I have nought in my coffers,â€™ saide the knyght,  
â€˜That I may prefer for shameâ€™:  
â€˜Litell John, go loke,â€™ sayde Robyn,  
â€˜Ne let not for no blame.  

â€˜Tel me truth,â€™ than saide Robyn,  
â€˜So God have parte of theeâ€™:  
â€˜I have no more but ten shelynges,â€™ sayde the knyght,  
â€˜So God have parte of me.â€™  

â€˜If thou have no more,â€™ sayde Robyn,  
â€˜I woll nat one peny;  
And yf thou have nede of any more,  
More shall I lend the.  

â€˜Go nowe furth, Littell Johnn,  
The truth tell thou me;  
If there be no more but ten shelinges,  
No peny that I se.â€™  

Lyttell Johnn sprede downe hys mantell  
Full fayre upon the grounde,  
And there he fonde in the knyghtÃ«s cofer  
But even halfe a pounde.  

Littell Johnn let it lye full styll,  
And went to hys maysteer full lowe;  
â€˜What tydynges, Johnn?â€™ sayde Robyn;  
â€˜Sir, the knyght is true inowe.â€™  

â€˜Fyll of the best wine,â€™ sayde Robyn,  
â€˜The knyght shall begynne;  
Moche wonder thinketh me  
Thy clothynge is so thinne.  

â€˜Tell me one worde,â€™ sayde Robyn,  
â€˜And counsel shal it be;  
I trowe thou wert made a knyght of force,  
Or ellys of yemanry.  

â€˜Or ellys thou hast been a sori husbande,  
And lyved in stroke and strife;  
An okerer, or ellis a lechoure,â€™ sayde Robyn,  
â€˜Wyth wronge hast led thy lyfe.â€™  

â€˜I am none of those,â€™ sayde the knyght,  
â€˜By God that madÃ« me;  
An hundred wynter here before  
Myn auncetres knyghtes have be.  

â€˜But oft it hath befal, Robyn,  
A man hath be disgrate;  
But God that sitteth in heven above  
May amende his state.  

â€˜Withyn this two yere, Robyne,â€™ he sayde,  
â€˜My neghbours well it knowe,  
Foure hundred pounde of gode money  
Ful well than myght I spende.  

â€˜Nowe have I no gode,â€™ saide the knyght,  
â€˜God hath shapen suche an ende,  
But my chyldren and my wyfe,  
Tyll God yt may amende.â€™  

â€˜In what maner,â€™ than sayde Robyn,  
â€˜Hast thou lorne thy rychesse?â€™  
â€˜For my greate foly,â€™ he sayde,  
â€˜And for my kyndÃ«nesse.  

â€˜I hade a sone, forsoth, Robyn,  
That shulde have ben myn ayre,  
Whanne he was twenty wynter olde,  
In felde wolde just full fayre.  

â€˜He slewe a knyght of Lancashire,  
And a squyer bolde;  
For to save him in his ryght  
My godes beth sette and solde.  

â€˜My londes beth sette to wedde, Robyn,  
Untyll a certayn day,  
To a ryche abbot here besyde  
Of Seynt Mari Abbey.â€™  

â€˜What is the som?â€™ sayde Robyn;  
â€˜Trouth than tell thou me.â€™  
â€˜Sir,â€™ he sayd, â€˜foure hundred pounde;  
The abbot told it to me.â€™  

â€˜Nowe and thou lese thy lond,â€™ sayde Robyn,  
â€˜What shall fall of thee?â€™  
â€˜Hastely I wol me buske,â€™ sayd the knyght,  
â€˜Over the saltÃ« see,  

â€˜And se where Criste was quyke and dede,  
On the mount of CalverÃ«;  
Fare wel, frende, and have gode day;  
It may no better be.â€™  

Teris fell out of hys iyen two;  
He wolde have gone hys way;  
â€˜Farewel, frende, and have gode day,  
I ne have no more to pay.â€™  

â€˜Where be thy frendÃ«s?â€™ sayde Robyn:  
â€˜Syr, never one wol me knowe;  
While I was rych ynowe at home  
Great boste than wolde they blowe.  

â€˜And nowe they renne away fro me,  
As bestis on a rowe;  
They take no more hede of me  
Thanne they had me never sawe.â€™  

For ruthe thanne wept Litell Johnn,  
Scarlok and Much in fere;  
â€˜Fyl of the best wyne,â€™ sayde Robyn,  
â€˜For here is a symple chere.  

â€˜Hast thou any frende,â€™ sayde Robyn,  
â€˜Thy borrowe that woldÃ« be?â€™  
â€˜I have none,â€™ than sayde the knyght,  
â€˜But God that dyed on tree.â€™  

â€˜Do away thy japis,â€™ than sayde Robyn,  
â€˜Thereof wol I right none;  
Wenest thou I wolde have God to borowe,  
Peter, Poule, or Johnn?

texts.name: King Arthur and Knights of the Round Table
texts.text:
King Arthur establishes a Round Table to ensure equality among knights, with no preference for one over another. He invites barons and knights to swear oaths of loyalty to him and his heirs, to maintain laws, justice, fellowship, and mutual aid. The table is furnished with seats, hiding places, a royal siege and throne in the center, and a sword placed where the king sits. After the oaths are sworn, Arthur appoints Sir Gawain as the first knight, chief of the Round Table, keeper of the sword, and first in sitting, rising, speaking, service, and obedience (repeated emphatically in the source text to emphasize his primacy).

In a separate account, Arthur consults Merlin about marriage, expressing love for Guinevere, daughter of King Leodegrance of Camelgard, who possesses the Round Table inherited from Arthur's father Uther. Merlin warns of future misery but advises the match. Arthur requests Guinevere's hand, referencing his prior rescue of Leodegrance with Kings Ban and Bors from King Ryence. Leodegrance agrees, sending Guinevere and the Round Table with 100 knights to Arthur.

The journey to Camelot involves royal travel by water and land, with sports, pastimes, minstrelsy, and tales. Sir Lancelot, newly at court, excels in games, wins praise for grace and hardihood, and captivates Guinevere with his tales and songs, especially at evening tents.

Upon arrival, Arthur hosts grand celebrations. He assembles knights from the Round Table group plus 28 others selected by Merlin, totaling the full number. The Archbishop blesses seats; each knight's name appears in gold on the back, except one: the Siege Perilous, fatal to sit in unless chosen by Heaven.

Young Gawain, Arthur's nephew, is knighted. A poor cowherd Aries petitions Arthur to knight his son Tor, who is passionate about knighthood despite his siblings' contentment in labor. Arthur knights Tor, noting his noble bearing. Merlin reveals Tor as the son of King Pellinore, a renowned knight. Pellinore arrives, honors Arthur, and is seated near the Perilous Seat.

Gawain, resenting Pellinore for killing his father Lot, plots murder with brother Gaheris but delays. Arthur addresses the knights, swearing them to truth, nobility, mercy, aid to ladies, and avoidance of treason, cruelty, or wrongful quarrels. He mandates annual Pentecost reports. The Round Table order is formalized, attracting world's best knights.

The wedding and coronation of Arthur and Guinevere are lavish: processions with kings bearing golden swords, queens with white doves, music, and joy. A high feast follows, with Arthur and Guinevere seated prominently.
